content: Is there any good reason for the test 4 to contain multiple spaces at the end of the second line ?

Just a remark: It's actually the same as https://www.codingame.com/training/easy/addem-up
But it's not a problem as it's presented in a completely different way.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Great puzzle, great explanation

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice puzzle and the new example makes the puzzle much better to understand. I changed the wording a bit and added the 'Compression'-Tag.

I really liked this puzzle and also learned something new. 
I think the statement needs to be improved though,

1.  Part 1 is really hard to understand without looking at the links. It says, that you need to find the two smallest frequencies, but you really need to find the two trees with smallest values. Maybe state in the beginning that you start with n trees where each tree corresponds to one char and has a value of the frequency of this char. I think an expample with more steps, where two leaves are joined together more than once, like ' 5 2 2 3 6',  would make the algorithm also clearer.
2. In 'Part 2' the value of d is '11', but should be '10'
3. The input section states that the list of frequency values is ordered, but its not. (or ordered by what?)

In the stub you could also use 'loopline n wi:int' instead of 'read weight:string(10000)' to make it more convenient to read the input.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: The Validator 6 as nearly 10,000 characters ! You need to increase the value in the stub generator.
Anyway nice puzzle. It was fun to experiment !

I like the idea.

But i have some troubles to solve it :

1. I do not know how the stub generator works but it's look like it's false for your input (at least in java). It's not a word but a line. And maybe you can use int array ?

2. In your “aabacdad” example, the binary code could be switch for 'b' and 'c'. In Huffman coding you build a table for a specific input that is use later for decoding. In case of equal frequency you make a choice that lead to different valid table.
You have to state a specific ordering when frequency is the same. Frequency as input is maybe not enough... a String input would be more appropriate ?! We could sort by character in case of equal frequency. But you have to think about it... how do we choose in this case :
dcbaa -> b(1) c(1) d(1) a(2)
(bc) then (ad) or (da) (character sorting or frequency sorting)...

1. Thanks for pointing it out, I was really confused on which to use on that one.

2. I was thinking about this as I was done doing the test cases. I have added some additional information, could you please check if I have answered your question properly?

for the case 
dcbaa -> d(1) c(1) b(1) a(2)
we first sequence them in the order they were seen
1. add b & c 
2. add d & a 
3. and finally (bc) & (da)
which would give you ((bc)(da)) with total weight 5
Thanks for looking out for me again. Really appreciate it.
Thanks for the suggestions. I really should have added one more character, but now I have updated the puzzle and also tried to make the input section clearer to understand.
Oh yeah, thanks. Will be more vigilant.

If i use queue ordering with "dcbaa" example i come up with :
d(1) c(1) b(1) a(2)
b(1) a(2) (dc)(2)
(dc)(2) (ba)(3)
((dc)(ba))(5)

am i right ?

1. ok
2. ok. I got it but i finally spend a lot of time searching to reach the same table as your implementation....
I swap left and right node ! I was sorting my list -> not valid. Then in my queue i was working from the tail after reading the explanation of the "dcbaa" example -> not working...

Maybe it will be error prone and a bit frustating as my solutions was not false ! but i'm just one opinion. I wait to see other comments

Yes, you are correct. I have been thinking about reducing the possible errors and decided to use the longest length. Could you try it with your previous code and check if that also satisfies as a valid solution?

All my versions work !

I think there is a mistake in the input of Test 5.

Maybe you can add one more test case to test the limit with N = 1, as i just saw that my solution does not handle this case and yours too !!

But I was thinking that you can ask for the final compression size in bit !? Or the winning size after compression (but for this one, watch out as N > 2^8)... so we are using the entire tree.
I already check with all my versions, i have same results.
Good to know and I updated my puzzle according to your insightful points. Could you give me more details for your last point tho?

The point is that (cause of me !!) it's possible now to solve it without a tree by playing with a list and a counter... So the puzzle is now more simple.
The Huffman code is about building a tree but here error prone cause of the choice we can make.
So instead of asking for the whole table you can ask for :

1. the final size after compression
Example with 4 1 1 2  -> a = 0, b = 110, c = 111, d = 11
The size is then 4 * 1 + 1 * 3 + 1 * 3 + 2 * 2 = 14 bits.
You keep an equivalent difficulty as the first version as we have to manage the tree to keep track of each length (even if i think we can still turn around !!). You ensure in a way that the table we build is correct by finding the optimal solution no matter we choose 0 for the left or the right or we keep these two minimum whatever their positions in the queue or list or... and this is a rather relevant question for the puzzle, at least i think.

2. how much space in bits you win after compression
Example with 4 1 1 2 -> 8 * 8 - 14 = 70 bits
This question is maybe more relevant but needs maybe to change the N constraints to justify that  a char occupy 8 bits with your test case.


Now the Test 5 is false. I use the N value and it's not 1001 but 1000 and frequencies are on two lines so your solution do not read the second. I think that you just duplicate the line by mistake ?!

I read and check the thing to approve your puzzle and the stubs generator is not valid at least for C, Objective C and PHP as the generation produce :
    char weight[1025];
    fgets(weight, 1025, stdin);
The whole line will not be read for some test case...

Sorry for the late reply, I finally updated the puzzle. Also. I assumed I had fixed Test 5. But it wasn't, which is weird cause the IDE would notify me that my solution was wrong when I submit the changes.

I am implementing your first suggestion, and to make sure my code was the optimum, I was checking for various other cases manually, which was really dumb of me. But I am somewhat certain that my answers for the test cases are right. 

Thank you so much, the puzzle wouldn't have turned out like this without your inputs :)
